newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Rate on Yugo c-bank bonds jumps to 102.88 pct.
newsitem.headline: Rate on Yugo c-bank bonds jumps to 102.88 pct.

text.p: The Yugoslav central bank raised the interest rate on its short-term bonds sharply and halved the paper's maturity on Friday, the Belgrade bourse said.
Bourse spokesman Milko Stimac said the National Bank of Yugoslavia (NBY) offered 40 million dinars in 30-day bonds at 102.88 percent annual interest rate at Friday's auction.
This compared with the previous 60.7 percent annual rate set when the NBY launched its first 60-day bonds in late June.
Stimac told Reuters the bank sold bonds worth just over three million dinars at Friday's sale.

One trader said a possible reason behind the sharp rise in the bond's interest rate and its truncated maturity was that the central bank had taken a jump in July inflation to 6.6 percent into account.
"They (the bank) apparently now need more money and they have realised that low interest rates on longer-dated paper attract no investors," another trader said.
No-one at the central bank was immediately available for comment.
A market analyst said that the jump in the rate on NBY bonds could be followed by a rise in the discount rate, which has been unchanged at 4.5 percent since June.
The central bank sets the discount rate each month using a basket that includes interest rates on the open money market, price rises, expected monetary developments, credit demand and money supply.
The central bank vice-governor Ratko Banovic recently said the NBY would keep the discount rate as its key instrument in regulating market liquidity.
